Climate change poses a significant threat to mangrove ecosystems, which are crucial for mitigating its impacts. To protect these ecosystems, it is essential to monitor their health, extent, and productivity. Traditionally, lower resolution satellite imagery or high-resolution unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) imagery has been used independently to monitor mangrove extent. To leverage the strengths of both data sources, we propose a hybrid neural network that combines a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) feature extractor with a Multilayer Perceptron (MLP) to accurately detect mangrove areas using both medium-resolution satellite and high-resolution drone imagery.

We present a comparison of our novel Hybrid CNN with algorithms previously applied to mangrove image classification on a dataset collected from consumer UAVs in Baja California Sur, Mexico, and achieve a 95% intersection over union (IOU) score for mangrove image classification, outperforming all our baselines.

Mangrove forests are coastal ecosystems that play a vital role in combating climate change through carbon sequestration, storing approximately twice as much carbon per cubic meter in their biomass as tropical rainforests. Mangroves are also a valuable resource for national governments to reduce their individual contributions to global climate change, as over 45 countries have mentioned mangroves in their Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) towards meeting the goals of the Paris Climate Agreement.

Mangroves not only help prevent the causes of climate change but also mitigate its impacts. Climate change increases the intensity and frequency of tropical storms, leading to larger storm surges and higher levels of coastal erosion. Mangroves act as natural storm breaks that reduce the physical impact of tropical storms on communities near mangrove forests by lessening wave energy. As a result, mangrove forests serve as an essential resource for local decision-makers to protect their constituents.

The ecosystem services of mangrove forests are estimated to provide $33,000 to $57,000 per hectare per year to associated local economies. Despite the benefits mangroves provide, they are at risk due to human activity, declining at a rate of 2% per year, and could release an estimated 4.2 billion tons of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere if deforestation continues at current rates.

Previous methods developed to track the extent of mangrove ecosystems have utilized single sources of data with lower resolution, such as hyperspectral bands or vegetation indices. The Global Mangrove Watch (GMW) utilizes ALOS PALSAR and Landsat satellite imagery to estimate global coverage of mangroves at a 25m resolution with a variant of the Random Forest algorithm. However, these predictions are lower resolution and temporally sparse, with the most recent predictions created in 2016.

To address the limitations of satellite images, remote sensing using consumer UAVs has emerged, allowing remote sensing scientists to resolve details in imagery not visible from satellites and record these images more frequently. Although these methods require in-situ surveys, UAVs show promise for ecology and remote sensing tasks, such as crop monitoring and forest management. UAVs have been used to record high-resolution images to measure mangrove extent, but are often dependent on expensive hyperspectral sensors to achieve high performance using images sourced from UAVs alone.

To further aid in the conservation of mangrove forests, we aim to combine the advantages of satellite and UAV remote sensing to create more accurate mangrove extent maps. In this paper, we propose a novel Hybrid CNN deep learning network that can be used to measure the extent of mangroves using a combination of medium-resolution 4-band Planetscope satellite and UAV imagery. We also describe methods used to acquire our dataset of mangrove imagery and labels and compare our mangrove classification network to baseline models and labels from previous related works.
